title: Parliamentary Traditions
description: Discover the fascinating customs, rules, and traditions of parliaments around the world

questions.question: In the British House of Commons, what is the role of the 'Speaker'?
options: Chief advisor to the Prime Minister
Presiding officer who maintains order in debates

questions.question: The ceremonial mace in the British Parliament symbolizes what?
options: Royal authority and the legitimacy of parliament

questions.question: In the U.S. Senate, what is a 'filibuster'?
options: A vote to impeach a senator
A formal introduction of a new bill
An extended debate used to delay or block a vote

questions.question: The British tradition of 'Black Rod' involves a door being slammed in the face of a messenger from the House of Lords. What does this symbolize?
options: The independence of the House of Commons from the Crown

questions.question: In the British Parliament, members of opposing parties are separated by a distance of how many sword-lengths?
What is 'Prime Minister's Questions' (PMQs) in the UK Parliament?
options: A written questionnaire for the PM
A weekly session where MPs can question the Prime Minister

questions.question: In many parliaments, what does 'crossing the floor' mean?
options: Changing party allegiance by sitting with the opposing side

questions.question: The State Opening of Parliament in the UK features the monarch reading a speech. Who actually writes this speech?
options: The government (the Prime Minister and cabinet)

questions.question: In the Canadian Parliament, what is the 'Throne Speech'?
options: A speech read by the Governor General outlining the government's agenda
A speech by the Prime Minister
A farewell address by a retiring MP

questions.question: Why are members of the British Parliament not allowed to clap during debates?
options: The acoustics make it too loud
Tradition dictates they use 'hear, hear' instead

questions.question: What is a 'whip' in parliamentary politics?
options: An official who ensures party members vote according to party lines

questions.question: In the U.S. Congress, what does the term 'lame duck session' refer to?
options: A session that lasts only one day
A session held after elections but before new members take office

questions.question: The Hansard is the official record of debates in the parliaments of which countries?
In India's Parliament, the 'Zero Hour' refers to what?
options: The hour when voting takes place
An informal period where MPs raise urgent matters without prior notice
The opening ceremony of each session

questions.question: What does a 'vote of no confidence' accomplish in a parliamentary system?
options: It can force the government or prime minister to resign
It dissolves the entire parliament permanently
